scenario: A new nationwide cancer screening program uses an advanced imaging test that can detect small tumors several years before they would normally cause symptoms. Hospital records show that, on average, patients whose cancers are found via screening live 5 years longer after diagnosis than patients whose cancers are found later when they present with symptoms. The hospital advertises the program by claiming that the screening test "adds 5 years to your life" if your cancer is found early.
claim: Because patients diagnosed by screening live 5 years longer after diagnosis than those diagnosed by symptoms, the screening test adds 5 years of life expectancy.
label: NO
causal_structure: X→Z1, Z1 shifts diagnosis time without changing death time; some tumors with longer natural history more likely in X-group (length bias)
key_insight: Starting the survival clock earlier makes post-diagnosis survival look longer even if the actual age at death is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Starting the survival clock earlier makes post-diagnosis survival look longer even if the actual age at death is unchanged.
answer_if_condition_1: If survival is measured from diagnosis, earlier detection (Screening detection (Exposure)) artificially inflates survival time without truly extending life.
answer_if_condition_2: If total lifespan or age at death is compared, any true benefit of Screening detection (Exposure) on Post-diagnosis survival time (Outcome) can be properly assessed.
wise_refusal: Comparing years lived after diagnosis is misleading when the time of diagnosis is shifted earlier by screening. The 5-year difference may simply reflect that the clock started sooner, while the actual date of death is the same in both groups. To determine whether the screening test truly prolongs life, we must compare total lifespan (age at death) or overall mortality, not just survival measured from the time of diagnosis.
gold_rationale: This scenario exemplifies lead time bias, where earlier detection (screening) increases the measured interval between diagnosis and death without necessarily changing when death occurs. The exposure (screening detection) moves the diagnosis date earlier (lead time), inflating post-diagnosis survival statistics even if the natural course of the disease is unchanged. Additionally, length bias can cause screening programs to preferentially detect slower-growing, less aggressive tumors, further exaggerating apparent survival benefits. Correct causal assessment requires examining all-cause or disease-specific mortality by age, rather than survival conditioned on the (screening-shifted) diagnosis time.

scenario: A new home blood pressure monitoring program encourages people to check their blood pressure daily with a smartphone-connected cuff. Data from the first year show that participants "survive" an average of 4 years longer after their first recorded high blood pressure reading than clinic patients whose hypertension was first detected during an ER visit for chest pain. The company advertises the device as "adding 4 extra years of life after hypertension diagnosis."
claim: The home blood pressure program increases patients’ lifespan by 4 years compared to usual care.
label: NO
var_X: Early BP detection via home monitoring (Exposure)
causal_structure: Z→X, Z shifts diagnosis earlier without changing death age; analysis conditions on diagnosis time so X appears to increase Y
key_insight: Earlier detection moves the starting point of the survival clock without necessarily delaying death, inflating post-diagnosis survival time without extending total life.
hidden_timestamp: Earlier detection moves the starting point of the survival clock without necessarily delaying death, inflating post-diagnosis survival time without extending total life.

wise_refusal: Comparing survival time from first recorded high blood pressure to death is misleading when one group is diagnosed much earlier. The home monitor may simply start the survival clock years before symptoms would have brought patients to the ER, even if everyone dies at the same age. To know whether the program truly extends life, we must compare age at death or total lifespan from a fixed baseline (e.g., age 40), not years lived after first diagnosis.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates lead time bias: early detection (X) creates an artificial increase in measured survival time after diagnosis (Y) because the clock starts sooner, not because death is delayed. The extra 4 years could be entirely due to the lead time (Z) between home detection and symptom-based detection, even if age at death is identical in both groups. Statistically, conditioning on time since diagnosis without aligning on a true biological starting point conflates earlier labeling with genuine benefit. Proper evaluation requires comparing mortality rates or total lifespan independent of the timing of first detection.

The observed association X–Y can therefore arise entirely from Z, even if X has no true causal effect on Y. Randomized controlled trials or well-adjusted longitudinal studies are needed to separate the effect of the supplement from the effect of the healthier lifestyle cluster. scenario: Hospital A has a 95% survival rate for a certain high‑risk surgery, while Hospital B reports only 90% survival for the same procedure. The ranking does not adjust for the fact that Hospital B is a regional referral center that takes most of the very complex cases, while Hospital A mostly operates on low‑risk patients.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that Hospital A is safer just from its higher overall survival rate because the hospitals treat very different types of patients. Hospital B likely receives a disproportionate share of the sickest and most complex cases, which inherently have higher mortality. To make a valid comparison, we must examine risk-adjusted or stratified outcomes within comparable severity categories (e.g., low-, medium-, and high-risk patients). Only after controlling for case mix can we tell which hospital is actually safer for a given patient profile.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates Simpson’s paradox driven by case mix confounding: patient severity (Z) affects both hospital assignment (X) and survival (Y). A regional referral center (Hospital B) preferentially receives more severe, high-risk cases, which lowers its crude survival rate even if its care quality is equal or superior. When outcomes are stratified by severity, Hospital B may have equal or better survival in every stratum, but the aggregated data reverses the association and makes Hospital A look better. The naive inference fails because it ignores this confounding structure and treats unadjusted overall survival rates as if they reflected causal effects of hospital choice.

To compare safety, we must examine risk‑adjusted outcomes—survival within comparable gestational age and risk groups—rather than crude totals.
gold_rationale: This scenario illustrates Simpson’s paradox driven by case mix confounding. Pregnancy risk category/gestational age (Z) affects both hospital assignment (X) and newborn survival (Y): the sickest, most premature cases are funneled to Ward Y, where mortality is intrinsically higher. When outcomes are aggregated across all risk levels, Ward Y appears to perform worse, but within each stratum of Z (e.g., term, late preterm, extreme prematurity) Ward Y may have equal or better survival than Ward X. key_insight: A small aggregate correlation between winter birth and schizophrenia does not identify a specific causal mechanism like prenatal infection without ruling out numerous alternative explanations.

Because these Z factors are numerous and only partly measured, the modest aggregate correlation between X and Y is multiply confounded and cannot uniquely identify a specific cause like prenatal infection. Proper causal inference would require individual-level exposure data and adjustment for these confounders, not mechanistic speculation based on an ecological pattern alone.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude that dairy consumption causes MS just because countries with higher average dairy intake have higher MS incidence. This is an ecological association at the group level, where many other factors—such as latitude, sunlight exposure, genetics, diagnostic practices, and overall healthcare systems—vary systematically between countries and can influence both diet patterns and MS detection. Without individual-level data that adjusts for these confounders, the observed country-level correlation does not support a specific causal claim about dairy for individuals.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates an ecological fallacy: an association observed at the aggregate (country) level is being overinterpreted as a causal relationship at the individual level. Latitude and related environmental, genetic, and healthcare factors likely influence both national dietary patterns and MS incidence (Z→X and Z→Y), creating a spurious correlation between dairy intake (X) and MS (Y) when analyzed by country. The ecological design masks within-country heterogeneity, so individuals who develop MS may not be the ones with high dairy intake, and the strength or direction of association could differ—or vanish—once individual-level confounders are controlled. Proper causal inference would require individual-level cohort or case–control data with careful adjustment for these correlated factors, not just cross-country averages.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude from a single improvement after multiple failed treatments that this patient is specifically a "responder" to Treatment E. Chronic pain naturally waxes and wanes, and after selecting a time of unusually severe pain to start yet another therapy, some regression toward the patient's typical pain level is expected even without an effective drug. To attribute the improvement to Treatment E, we would need evidence such as repeated, reproducible improvement with re-challenge, randomized comparison to placebo or alternatives, or consistent benefit across similar patients starting at comparable baseline severity.
gold_rationale: The case exemplifies regression to the mean: Treatment E is initiated when the patient's pain is at an unusually bad level after a run of failures, making subsequent improvement statistically likely regardless of the specific treatment. The doctor misattributes this expected regression to the drug's unique efficacy, labeling the patient a "responder" based on a single episode. Because no control group or repeated on–off comparison exists, we cannot separate the natural fluctuation of chronic pain from any real pharmacologic effect. Proper causal inference would require either randomized data or within-patient re-challenge that shows improvement reliably tied to Treatment E rather than to timing alone.

scenario: A patient with intermittent palpitations presents to clinic during a week of unusually frequent episodes. answer_if_condition_2: If Beta-Blocker B initiation (Exposure) was initiated at typical values or if a control group shows the same pattern, regression to the mean may not explain the effect.
wise_refusal: Palpitations often wax and wane over time, and patients tend to seek care when symptoms are at their worst. Starting Beta-Blocker B at a peak virtually guarantees that some improvement will occur even without an effective treatment, due to regression to the mean. To claim this patient is a true "responder" to the drug, we would need repeated on–off trials or comparison with a control group that also started at a similar peak. Single pre–post observations after initiating therapy at a high point cannot reliably attribute the change to the medication.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates regression to the mean: selecting patients for treatment when their symptoms are unusually severe biases subsequent measurements toward apparent improvement. The exposure (starting Beta-Blocker B) is temporally linked to a high-symptom state, and the outcome (reduced palpitations) partly reflects natural return toward average symptom frequency, not necessarily drug efficacy. Without a comparison group that also begins at a peak or repeated cross-over evidence, we cannot distinguish drug effect from expected statistical regression. The naive inference treats a predictable statistical artifact as proof of individual pharmacologic responsiveness.

scenario: A national health registry reports that patients whose chronic kidney disease was detected through routine blood testing survived an average of three years longer after diagnosis than patients whose kidney disease was discovered after symptoms developed.
claim: Routine screening for kidney disease increases patient lifespan by three years.
label: NO
causal_structure: Screening advances the date of diagnosis without necessarily changing the date of death, inflating post-diagnosis survival statistics without extending actual lifespan.
key_insight: Earlier diagnosis can mechanically increase measured survival even when mortality is unchanged.
hidden_timestamp: Did screened patients actually die later, or were they simply diagnosed earlier?

conditional_answers.condition_1: If screening only advances diagnosis timing, the survival difference is a statistical artifact of lead-time bias.
conditional_answers.condition_2: If screened patients die at older ages, screening may provide a real survival benefit.

wise_refusal: Longer survival after diagnosis does not prove longer life. Without evidence that screening delays death or reduces mortality, the claim of added lifespan is not supported.
gold_rationale: Post-diagnosis survival depends on when the clock starts. Screening can extend measured survival by diagnosing disease earlier even if patients die at the same age.

scenario: A neurologist tells a patient that because their early-stage Alzheimer’s disease was detected through routine cognitive screening rather than after noticeable symptoms appeared, they are expected to live four years longer after diagnosis than similar patients diagnosed later.

conditional_answers.condition_1: If the patient dies at the same age regardless of detection timing, the longer survival reflects lead-time bias.
conditional_answers.condition_2: If early detection enables interventions that delay death, then screening may extend life.

wise_refusal: The claim assumes longer post-diagnosis survival equals longer life. Without evidence that early detection delays death, the apparent benefit may be entirely due to lead-time bias.
gold_rationale: Lead-time bias arises when earlier diagnosis inflates survival duration without affecting mortality. Survival statistics must be interpreted relative to age at death, not diagnosis date.

scenario: A clinic reviews outcomes for patients whose cancers were detected through routine screening versus those detected after symptoms. Screened patients appear to survive five years longer when survival is measured from the diagnosis date.

scenario: A cancer screening program detects tumors earlier than symptom-based diagnosis. Patients diagnosed via screening live an average of five years longer after diagnosis than those diagnosed after symptoms appear.

conditional_answers.condition_1: If screening only advances diagnosis timing without delaying death, the apparent survival benefit is due to lead-time bias and does not reflect increased lifespan.

wise_refusal: The claim that screening adds five years to life is unsupported. Earlier detection can increase measured post-diagnosis survival without delaying death. Without evidence that screening increases age at death or reduces mortality, a causal benefit cannot be concluded.
gold_rationale: Screening changes the starting point of survival measurement. Longer survival after diagnosis can be entirely explained by lead-time or length bias rather than an actual extension of life.

scenario: A hospital introduces routine cancer screening that identifies tumors earlier than clinical symptoms. Screen-detected patients show an average increase of five years in survival measured from diagnosis compared to symptom-detected patients.

wise_refusal: The evidence does not support the claim that screening extends life. Measuring survival from diagnosis can exaggerate benefits when detection is earlier but death timing is unchanged. Without proof of delayed mortality, the causal claim fails.
gold_rationale: An apparent improvement in survival can result entirely from earlier detection shifting the survival clock, not from an actual increase in lifespan.

scenario: A new nationwide cancer screening program uses an advanced imaging test that can detect small tumors several years before they would normally cause symptoms. Hospital records show that, on average, patients whose cancers are found via screening live 5 years longer after diagnosis than patients whose cancers are found later when they present with symptoms. The hospital advertises the program by claiming that the screening test "adds 5 years to your life" if your cancer is found early.

label: NO
causal_structure: X→Z1, Z1 shifts diagnosis time without changing death time; some tumors with longer natural history more likely in X-group (length bias)
key_insight: Starting the survival clock earlier makes post-diagnosis survival look longer even if the actual age at death is unchanged.

conditional_answers.condition_1: If only survivors/successes are observed and failures are missing, the claim is not supported.

wise_refusal: Comparing years lived after diagnosis is misleading when the time of diagnosis is shifted earlier by screening. The 5-year difference may simply reflect that the clock started sooner, while the actual date of death is the same in both groups. To determine whether the screening test truly prolongs life, we must compare total lifespan (age at death) or overall mortality, not just survival measured from the time of diagnosis.
gold_rationale: This scenario exemplifies lead time bias, where earlier detection (screening) increases the measured interval between diagnosis and death without necessarily changing when death occurs. The exposure (screening detection) moves the diagnosis date earlier (lead time), inflating post-diagnosis survival statistics even if the natural course of the disease is unchanged. Additionally, length bias can cause screening programs to preferentially detect slower-growing, less aggressive tumors, further exaggerating apparent survival benefits. Correct causal assessment requires examining all-cause or disease-specific mortality by age, rather than survival conditioned on the (screening-shifted) diagnosis time.

scenario: A new home blood pressure monitoring program encourages people to check their blood pressure daily with a smartphone-connected cuff. The company advertises the device as "adding 4 extra years of life after hypertension diagnosis."

wise_refusal: Comparing survival time from first recorded high blood pressure to death is misleading when one group is diagnosed much earlier. The home monitor may simply start the survival clock years before symptoms would have brought patients to the ER, even if everyone dies at the same age. To know whether the program truly extends life, we must compare age at death or total lifespan from a fixed baseline (e.g., age 40), not years lived after first diagnosis.
gold_rationale: This case illustrates lead time bias: early detection (X) creates an artificial increase in measured survival time after diagnosis (Y) because the clock starts sooner, not because death is delayed. The extra 4 years could be entirely due to the lead time (Z) between home detection and symptom-based detection, even if age at death is identical in both groups. Statistically, conditioning on time since diagnosis without aligning on a true biological starting point conflates earlier labeling with genuine benefit. Proper evaluation requires comparing mortality rates or total lifespan independent of the timing of first detection.

scenario: People who take vitamin D supplements have 30% lower rates of depression than those who do not, according to a large observational survey. Supplement users in the study also tended to exercise regularly, spend more time outdoors, and have higher incomes.

wise_refusal: This is an observational association that is heavily confounded by "healthy user" factors: people who take vitamin D are more likely to exercise, get sunlight, and have higher socioeconomic status, all of which reduce depression risk. Without randomization or strong adjustment for these variables, we cannot infer that vitamin D itself prevents depression. Randomized trials of vitamin D for mood have generally shown mixed or null effects, suggesting the supplement is more of a marker of a healthy lifestyle than a causal antidepressant.
gold_rationale: Vitamin D supplementation (X) is not randomly assigned; it is chosen more often by people who are health-conscious, physically active, and higher SES (Z variables). Those same characteristics causally reduce depression risk (Y), so Z→X and Z→Y confounding can generate an apparent protective effect of X even if X has no true impact on Y. The naive comparison of depression rates between users and non-users attributes the effect of Z to X. Proper causal inference would require randomization or careful adjustment/stratification on these confounders to isolate any true effect of vitamin D.

scenario: An observational study finds that adults who regularly take omega-3 fish oil capsules have 25% lower rates of anxiety disorders than those who do not supplement. Further analysis shows that regular supplement users are more likely to follow a Mediterranean diet, exercise at least 3 times per week, and attend routine preventive checkups. A supplement company advertises fish oil as a “natural cure for anxiety” based on these findings.
claim: Because fish oil supplement users have lower anxiety rates, taking fish oil capsules will prevent or cure anxiety disorders.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z1→X, Z1→Y; Z2→X, Z2→Y; Z3→X, Z3→Y
key_insight: People who choose to take supplements tend to be more health-conscious and advantaged overall, which lowers anxiety risk independently of the supplement itself.
hidden_timestamp: People who choose to take supplements tend to be more health-conscious and advantaged overall, which lowers anxiety risk independently of the supplement itself.

conditional_answers.condition_1: If a third factor affects both the supposed cause and outcome and is not controlled, the claim is not supported.
conditional_answers.condition_2: If that confounder is controlled (or assignment is effectively random), the claim is more credible.

wise_refusal: Observational associations between supplement use and better mental health are highly vulnerable to healthy user bias: people who regularly buy and take fish oil are also more likely to eat well, exercise, have stable employment, and seek timely care, all of which can reduce anxiety risk. Without randomization or very strong adjustment for these lifestyle and socioeconomic factors, we cannot attribute the lower anxiety rates to the fish oil itself. The study shows that supplement users differ systematically from non-users, not that the capsules are an effective treatment or preventive for anxiety.
gold_rationale: This scenario illustrates classic confounding: underlying traits like health consciousness, diet quality, exercise habits, and socioeconomic status (Z) influence both the likelihood of taking fish oil supplements (X) and the risk of anxiety disorders (Y). The observed association X–Y can therefore arise entirely from Z, even if X has no true causal effect on Y. Randomized controlled trials or well-adjusted longitudinal studies are needed to separate the effect of the supplement from the effect of the healthier lifestyle cluster. Marketing claims that fish oil “prevents anxiety” based solely on such observational data are causally unwarranted.

gold_rationale: This case illustrates Simpson’s paradox driven by case mix confounding: patient severity (Z) affects both hospital assignment (X) and survival (Y). A regional referral center (Hospital B) preferentially receives more severe, high-risk cases, which lowers its crude survival rate even if its care quality is equal or superior. When outcomes are stratified by severity, Hospital B may have equal or better survival in every stratum, but the aggregated data reverses the association and makes Hospital A look better. The naive inference fails because it ignores this confounding structure and treats unadjusted overall survival rates as if they reflected causal effects of hospital choice.

key_insight: Small population-level effects can be misleading when interpreted as evidence for specific individual-level causes.
hidden_timestamp: Was prenatal infection directly measured at the individual level before the later onset of schizophrenia, independent of seasonal and social confounders?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If seasonal differences reflect changes in diagnosis, reporting, or conception patterns, then birth month is only a proxy and not a cause.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If controlled individual-level studies link prenatal infection timing to schizophrenia outcomes, the causal claim would be more plausible.

wise_refusal: The available data do not support the claim that seasonal infections cause schizophrenia. Aggregate correlations can arise from many confounders and should not be overinterpreted as causal.
gold_rationale: A weak seasonal association combined with multiple plausible confounders means the observed pattern cannot justify a specific biological causal explanation.

scenario: A student scores extremely poorly on several exams, then improves after switching to a new tutor.
claim: The new tutor caused the improvement.
label: NO
causal_structure: Performance varies over time, and changes are often made at low points.
key_insight: Improvement is statistically likely after extreme lows.
hidden_timestamp: Would improvement have occurred without changing tutors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If yes, the effect is regression.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If improvement consistently follows this tutor, causation is possible.

wise_refusal: Single improvements after poor performance are unreliable evidence.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean explains the apparent effect. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: An athlete performs poorly for several games, then improves after changing training routines.
claim: The new routine is uniquely effective.
label: NO
causal_structure: Performance slumps naturally resolve over time.
key_insight: Late changes get credit for natural rebound.
hidden_timestamp: Do similar rebounds occur without routine changes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If yes, regression explains the pattern.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no, training may help.

wise_refusal: Attributing recovery to the last change ignores natural fluctuation.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean explains why performance rebounds appear causal. This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: A patient’s chronic pain improved after trying the 5th treatment. Their doctor notes: “You’re a responder to Treatment E. We should have tried it first.”
claim: The final treatment caused the improvement and should have been used first.
label: NO

Z: Natural fluctuation/regression (Z) → Y; sequential trials select extremes

causal_structure: Improvement after many failures is often regression to the mean, not evidence the last treatment worked.
key_insight: Would similar improvement have occurred without switching to the final treatment?
hidden_timestamp: If change occurred after an extreme baseline: Apparent improvement is likely regression to the mean, not treatment effect.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If improvement repeats reliably after the intervention: Then the intervention may be causally effective.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Improvement after multiple failed treatments is consistent with regression to the mean. One post-hoc improvement does not show the last treatment caused the change; we would need repeated responses or controlled comparisons.

wise_refusal: Regression To Mean (Sequential Trial Artifact) applies: Improvement after many failures is often regression to the mean, not evidence the last treatment worked.
gold_rationale: Ankit Rai This case demonstrates a clear causal reasoning pattern that requires careful analysis of the underlying mechanisms.

scenario: People begin an intervention when symptoms are at their worst (or performance is unusually poor). A follow-up measurement shortly after shows large improvement.
claim: The intervention caused the improvement seen at follow-up.
label: NO
causal_structure: Starting at an extreme guarantees some movement back toward typical levels on the next measurement, even without an effective intervention.
key_insight: Improvement after an extreme observation can be a statistical artifact (regression to the mean).
hidden_timestamp: Do comparable controls who started at the same extreme improve similarly without the intervention?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If controls improve similarly from the same extreme baseline, the observed gain is regression to the mean, not a treatment effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If improvement reliably exceeds matched controls or repeats when the intervention is reintroduced, a causal effect becomes plausible.

wise_refusal: A single improvement after an extreme baseline is weak evidence. Without matched controls (or repeated on/off evidence), we cannot separate natural fluctuation from treatment effect.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean predicts that extreme measurements move toward average on re-measurement; causal attribution requires controls matched on baseline extremity.

scenario: After several unsuccessful therapies for chronic pain, a patient experiences improvement following their fifth treatment. The physician concludes the patient is a responder to Treatment E and suggests it should have been used first.
claim: Treatment E causes pain improvement.
label: NO
causal_structure: Chronic pain symptoms fluctuate over time, so improvement after multiple failed treatments can reflect regression to the mean rather than a causal effect of the fifth treatment.
key_insight: Improvement after many trials may occur by chance due to natural symptom variation rather than treatment efficacy.
hidden_timestamp: Did the patient experience similar improvement with repeated administrations of Treatment E, or was this a single observation after many trials?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the improvement occurred once after several treatments due to natural fluctuation, then attributing it to Treatment E is unreliable.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the patient repeatedly improves specifically after Treatment E and not others, this would support a responder effect.

wise_refusal: The claim that the patient is a responder to Treatment E is unsupported. Single improvements after multiple treatment attempts can arise from natural symptom fluctuation and do not establish treatment efficacy.
gold_rationale: Chronic pain naturally varies, and after repeated failures, any subsequent improvement is likely regression to the mean rather than evidence that a specific treatment caused the change.

scenario: A patient with long-standing pain reports relief only after the fifth therapy tried, leading the clinician to state that Treatment E is uniquely effective for this patient.
claim: The patient is a responder to Treatment E.
label: NO
causal_structure: Symptoms of chronic pain vary over time, making improvement after a sequence of treatments likely even in the absence of a true treatment effect.
key_insight: Single-case improvement late in a treatment sequence does not demonstrate causality.
hidden_timestamp: Was pain relief consistently observed when Treatment E was administered again, or did improvement occur only once after many trials?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If pain improved only once after many treatment attempts, the change may reflect regression to the mean rather than a causal response to Treatment E.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If repeated exposure to Treatment E reliably produces improvement, it would support the claim of a treatment-specific responder.

wise_refusal: There is insufficient evidence to conclude the patient is a responder to Treatment E. Improvements following multiple failed treatments can occur due to regression to the mean and should not be overinterpreted.
gold_rationale: Inferring treatment efficacy from a single improvement after a sequence of therapies ignores natural symptom variability and the tendency for extreme symptoms to move toward average levels over time.

scenario: A cancer screening test detects tumors earlier. Patients diagnosed via screening live 5 years longer after diagnosis than those diagnosed by symptoms. Hospital promotes screening as “adding 5 years to life.”
claim: Routine screening increases patients’ actual lifespan by about five years.
label: NO
causal_structure: X → earlier diagnosis; earlier diagnosis inflates Y without changing death time
key_insight: Screening can start the survival clock earlier without extending total lifespan (lead-time/length bias).
hidden_timestamp: Did screened patients actually die later, or were they just diagnosed earlier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If screening only shifts diagnosis earlier: The longer post-diagnosis survival is an artifact of lead-time/length bias, not longer life.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If screening delays death (mortality falls): Then screening could provide a real survival benefit.

wise_refusal: Longer survival after diagnosis does not prove longer life. Screening can move the diagnosis date earlier without delaying death. We need evidence that screening reduces mortality or increases age at death, not just post-diagnosis survival.
gold_rationale: Lead Time Bias (Survival Measurement Artifact) applies: Screening can start the survival clock earlier without extending total lifespan (lead-time/length bias).

scenario: A clinic reviews outcomes for patients whose cancers were detected through routine screening versus those detected after symptoms. Screened patients appear to survive five years longer when survival is measured from the diagnosis date.
claim: Because screening finds cancer earlier, it adds five years to patients’ lifespan.
label: NO
causal_structure: Earlier detection shifts the diagnosis timestamp forward; survival-from-diagnosis increases even if the death date is unchanged.
key_insight: A longer time from diagnosis to death can be a measurement artifact when diagnosis occurs earlier.
hidden_timestamp: Did screening actually delay death (older age at death), or did it only move the diagnosis date earlier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If death occurs at the same age and only diagnosis is earlier, the five-year ‘benefit’ is lead-time/length bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If screening reduces mortality or shifts death to later ages, then screening could provide a real survival benefit.

wise_refusal: You can’t conclude screening adds years to life from post-diagnosis survival alone. We need evidence of reduced mortality or later death, not an earlier start of the clock.
gold_rationale: Lead-time bias inflates measured survival by starting the survival clock earlier; the proper comparison is age at death or mortality rates, not survival time since diagnosis.

scenario: People who take vitamin D supplements have 30% lower rates of depression. A wellness company markets vitamin D as “nature’s antidepressant.”
claim: Taking the supplement directly prevents depression.
label: NO
causal_structure: Z → X and Z → Y (healthy-user/SES confounding)
key_insight: Supplement users differ systematically (health behaviors, SES), so the association is confounded.
hidden_timestamp: Do supplement users differ in baseline health, activity, or socioeconomic status?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If confounders explain group differences: The association is non-causal; X is a marker of Z which drives Y.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If effects persist after adjustment/RCT: Then X may have an independent causal effect.

wise_refusal: This is an observational association and is likely confounded by healthy-user and socioeconomic differences. Without randomization or strong adjustment for baseline lifestyle and SES, we cannot attribute lower depression rates to the supplement itself.
gold_rationale: Confounding (Healthy User Correlation) applies: Supplement users differ systematically (health behaviors, SES), so the association is confounded.

scenario: A cross-sectional survey finds that people who opt into a wellness activity (e.g., supplements, mindfulness workshops, resilience training) report lower depression than non-participants.
claim: Participating in the wellness activity directly prevents depression.
label: NO
causal_structure: Self-selection into wellness participation correlates with health consciousness, resources, and baseline mental health—factors that also affect depression.
key_insight: The association can be explained by healthy-user and socioeconomic confounding rather than a causal program effect.
hidden_timestamp: After controlling for baseline mental health, SES, and lifestyle, does the association persist?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If participants are healthier or wealthier at baseline, the observed difference is confounding (healthy-user bias), not causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the effect remains within matched groups or under random assignment, the intervention may have a true causal benefit.

wise_refusal: Voluntary wellness participation is heavily confounded. Without randomization or strong adjustment for baseline differences, we cannot attribute lower depression to the activity itself.
gold_rationale: Healthy-user bias and SES differences can fully produce the observed correlation; causal claims require controlling confounders or randomized evidence.

scenario: Hospital A has a 95% surgery survival rate while Hospital B has 90%. A patient chooses Hospital A as “clearly better.”
claim: The higher overall survival rate proves Hospital A is better for all patients.
label: NO
causal_structure: Case mix/severity (Z) differs by hospital; aggregation can reverse within-stratum effects
key_insight: Raw averages can mislead when hospitals treat different severity mixes (Simpson’s paradox).
hidden_timestamp: How do outcomes compare within the same severity/risk category?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If outcomes reverse within relevant strata: The aggregate comparison is misleading (Simpson’s paradox).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If one option wins within every stratum: Then the aggregate ranking likely reflects a real difference.

wise_refusal: Raw outcome rates ignore case mix. If one hospital treats sicker patients, its overall survival can look worse even if it performs better within each severity group. We need risk-adjusted or stratified comparisons.
gold_rationale: Simpsons Paradox (Case Mix Confounding) applies: Raw averages can mislead when hospitals treat different severity mixes (Simpson’s paradox).

scenario: Two institutions are compared using a single overall success rate. Institution A looks better on the aggregate metric, but Institution B serves a higher proportion of high-risk cases.
claim: Institution A is better than Institution B because its overall success rate is higher.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate rates mix different case mixes; stratifying by baseline risk can reverse the apparent advantage.
key_insight: Overall averages can mislead when subgroup composition differs; compare within strata or risk-adjust.
hidden_timestamp: When you compare within the same risk/severity strata, does the ranking reverse?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If B outperforms within each comparable stratum, the aggregate advantage of A is Simpson’s paradox driven by case mix.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If A remains better within each stratum, then the aggregate result likely reflects true quality differences.

wise_refusal: Raw aggregate rates are not comparable across groups with different baseline risk. We need stratified or risk-adjusted outcomes before concluding one is better.
gold_rationale: Simpson’s paradox occurs when subgroup distributions differ; conclusions should be drawn from stratified/risk-adjusted comparisons, not unadjusted aggregates.

scenario: Children born in winter months have slightly higher rates of schizophrenia. A re- searcher proposes: “Seasonal infections during pregnancy cause schizophrenia.”
claim: Seasonal infections during pregnancy cause schizophrenia.
label: NO
causal_structure: Multiple confounders (Z) drive both X and Y; aggregate correlation ≠ individual causation
key_insight: Small population-level correlations don’t identify individual-level mechanisms (ecological fallacy).
hidden_timestamp: Does the association hold within matched individuals after controlling for key confounders?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the pattern is only at the group level: You cannot infer individual causation from aggregate correlations.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the effect holds in individual-level matched data: Then a causal mechanism becomes more plausible.

wise_refusal: A weak population-level correlation does not identify a causal mechanism for individuals. Many confounders (SES, conception timing, reporting, diagnostic practices) can generate the pattern, so causal claims about infections require stronger evidence.
gold_rationale: Ecological Fallacy (Aggregate Pattern Overinterpretation) applies: Small population-level correlations don’t identify individual-level mechanisms (ecological fallacy).

scenario: A regional dataset shows that areas with higher exposure prevalence also have higher outcome prevalence. A report concludes the exposure causes the outcome in each individual resident.
claim: The area-level exposure causes the outcome for individuals living in that area.
label: NO
causal_structure: Group-level associations can arise from population composition and confounders; they do not identify individual-level causal mechanisms.
key_insight: You cannot infer individual causation from aggregated correlations without individual-level analysis.
hidden_timestamp: Does the relationship hold at the individual level after controlling for SES, access, and other confounders?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level analysis (with confounders controlled) removes the association, the claim is an ecological fallacy.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a controlled individual-level analysis still shows an effect, the exposure may be causal—but the aggregate result alone is insufficient evidence.

wise_refusal: Aggregate patterns do not justify individual causal claims. Individual-level data and confounder control are required before concluding causation.
gold_rationale: Ecological fallacy: inferring individual-level causation from group-level associations; composition/confounding can drive regional correlations.

scenario: A randomized workplace wellness trial offers free omega-3 supplements to employees, randomly assigned to individuals rather than individual choice. After one year, employees in offices receiving supplements show significantly lower rates of clinically diagnosed anxiety compared to control offices.
claim: Omega-3 supplementation reduces anxiety rates.
label: YES
causal_structure: X → Y The relationship requires careful causal analysis to avoid spurious conclusions.
key_insight: Randomized exposure breaks the healthy-user confounding pattern.
hidden_timestamp: Were supplements assigned independently of individual health behaviors?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If supplementation was randomly assigned, health consciousness and SES do not confound the effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If individuals self-selected into supplementation, healthy-user bias could explain the result.

wise_refusal: Given randomized assignment, the causal claim is justified because health consciousness, SES, and physical activity are balanced by design. This conclusion depends on the assumption that randomization was successful and that no post-treatment selection, noncompliance, or differential diagnosis occurred. If participants self-selected into treatment or if outcome measurement differed by group, the causal interpretation would not hold.
gold_rationale: The scenario explicitly removes self-selection. Apparent healthy-user confounders are balanced by design, making the causal claim valid.

scenario: Regions with higher rates of childhood vaccination also report higher autism diagnosis rates. A commentator argues that vaccines cause autism in individual children.
claim: Vaccinations cause autism in children.
label: NO
causal_structure: Population composition and diagnostic practices (Z) influence both exposure and reported outcome; group-level correlation ≠ individual causation
key_insight: Area-level correlations can reflect reporting and access differences rather than biological causation.
hidden_timestamp: Does the association persist at the individual level after controlling for healthcare access and diagnostic intensity?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the association disappears in individual-level data, the claim is an ecological fallacy.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If a controlled individual-level analysis shows a consistent effect, further causal investigation is warranted.

wise_refusal: A regional correlation does not establish individual causation. Differences in access to care, reporting, and diagnostic practices can fully explain the pattern without any causal effect of vaccination.
gold_rationale: Ecological Fallacy (Aggregate Pattern Overinterpretation): Inferring individual-level causation from population-level associations is invalid.

scenario: Cities with higher average air pollution levels also show higher asthma hospitalization rates. A report concludes that air pollution exposure causes asthma attacks in every individual resident.
claim: Air pollution causes asthma attacks in individuals living in polluted cities.
label: NO
causal_structure: Group-level exposure-outcome associations can arise from population composition and structural confounders, not individual-level causal effects.
key_insight: Aggregate environmental correlations do not automatically translate into individual causal mechanisms.
hidden_timestamp: Does individual-level exposure predict asthma attacks after controlling for baseline health and access to care?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level adjustment removes the association, the group-level claim is an ecological fallacy.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If individual exposure consistently predicts attacks after adjustment, a causal mechanism becomes plausible.

wise_refusal: Population-level correlations alone cannot justify individual causal claims. Individual exposure data and confounder control are required to establish causation.
gold_rationale: Ecological fallacy applies: group-level correlations may reflect population composition, access, or reporting differences rather than individual causal effects.

scenario: Cities with higher average air pollution levels report higher asthma hospitalization rates. A public health report argues that exposure to higher air pollution increases the risk of asthma attacks among individuals living in those cities. Critics note that highly polluted cities also tend to be denser, have poorer baseline population health, and greater access to hospitals that diagnose and admit asthma cases more frequently.
claim: Air pollution exposure increases the risk of asthma attacks for individuals living in polluted cities.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Group-level association; individual-level causation unclear
key_insight: Aggregate environmental correlations may arise from population composition and structural confounders rather than individual-level causal mechanisms.
hidden_timestamp: Does individual-level pollution exposure predict asthma attacks after controlling for baseline health, population density, and healthcare access?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level pollution exposure remains associated with asthma attacks after adjusting for baseline health, density, and access to care, then a causal relationship between pollution exposure and asthma risk at the individual level is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the association disappears after controlling for baseline health, density, and healthcare access, then the observed pattern reflects population composition and healthcare utilization rather than an individual-level causal effect.

wise_refusal: Population-level correlations cannot determine whether air pollution causes asthma attacks at the individual level. Without individual exposure data and adequate control for baseline health and healthcare access, the claim remains unresolved.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because city-level pollution and hospitalization correlations do not establish whether pollution exposure causally increases asthma risk at the individual level or whether the association is driven by population density, baseline health differences, and healthcare utilization.

scenario: Cities with higher average levels of urban noise exposure report higher rates of COPD-related emergency department visits. A public health report argues that chronic exposure to high noise levels increases the risk of acute COPD exacerbations among individuals living in those cities. Critics note that high-noise cities also tend to be denser, have older populations with poorer baseline lung function, and greater access to hospitals that more frequently diagnose and admit COPD cases.
claim: Chronic urban noise exposure increases the risk of acute COPD exacerbations for individuals living in high-noise cities.
label: AMBIGUOUS

Z: Baseline lung function and age distribution

causal_structure: Group-level association; individual-level causation unclear
key_insight: Aggregate environmental correlations may arise from population composition and structural confounders rather than individual-level causal mechanisms.
hidden_timestamp: Does individual-level noise exposure predict acute COPD exacerbations after controlling for age, baseline lung function, population density, and healthcare access?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If individual-level noise exposure remains associated with acute COPD exacerbations after adjusting for age, lung function, density, and access to care, then a causal relationship between noise exposure and COPD exacerbation risk at the individual level is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the association disappears after controlling for age, baseline lung function, density, and healthcare access, then the observed pattern reflects population composition and healthcare utilization rather than an individual-level causal effect.

wise_refusal: Population-level correlations cannot determine whether urban noise exposure causes acute COPD exacerbations at the individual level. Without individual exposure data and adequate control for baseline lung function, age, and healthcare access, the claim remains unresolved.
gold_rationale: The claim is ambiguous because city-level noise exposure and COPD emergency visit correlations do not establish whether noise exposure causally increases exacerbation risk at the individual level or whether the association is driven by population age structure, baseline lung disease severity, and healthcare utilization.

scenario: Researchers examined medical records of patients who survived a high-risk surgical procedure and observed that nearly all surviving patients had received an aggressive postoperative rehabilitation protocol. They concluded that the rehabilitation protocol caused higher survival rates. Patients who died shortly after surgery were not included in the analysis.
claim: Aggressive postoperative rehabilitation causes higher survival after surgery.
label: NO
causal_structure: Observed Survivors <- Selection -> X and Y
key_insight: Only observing survivors hides failed cases, creating a false association between X and success.
hidden_timestamp: Were outcomes for non-surviving patients observed and included?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If both survivors and non-survivors were analyzed, the effect of rehabilitation could be evaluated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only survivors are observed, causal inference is invalid.

wise_refusal: We would refuse to evaluate this causal claim if only surviving patients were observed and failures were unmeasured, because conditioning on survival induces bias. That is exactly the case here, so the claim cannot be supported.
gold_rationale: This case exhibits survivorship bias. The analysis includes only patients who survived long enough to receive rehabilitation, while patients who died are excluded. Because failed cases with and without rehabilitation are missing, the observed association cannot support a causal claim.

scenario: A screening test for a rare disease affecting 1 in 1,000 people has 99% sensitivity and 95% specificity. A patient tests positive, and a clinician concludes that the patient almost certainly has the disease because the test is highly accurate.
claim: The patient almost certainly has the disease after a positive test.
label: NO
causal_structure: Base Rate + Test Accuracy -> Posterior Probability
key_insight: Ignoring low base rates leads to severe overestimation of P(Disease | Positive).
hidden_timestamp: Was the base rate of the disease incorporated into the probability estimate?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If base rates are included, the posterior probability is low despite a positive test.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If base rates are ignored, the probability is grossly overestimated.

wise_refusal: We would refuse this claim if the conclusion ignores disease prevalence and relies only on test accuracy, because diagnostic probability requires Bayesian updating. That is exactly what occurs here, so the claim is invalid.
gold_rationale: This case demonstrates base rate neglect. Although the test is accurate, the disease is rare, so false positives greatly outnumber true positives. The probability of disease given a positive result remains low, contradicting the claim.

scenario: A patient with a common cold took an herbal remedy recommended by a friend. Three days later, the cold symptoms resolved. The patient concluded that the herbal remedy cured the cold and recommended it to others.
claim: The herbal remedy cured the cold.
label: NO
causal_structure: Treatment -> Recovery (assumed)
key_insight: Temporal sequence alone does not establish causality.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a control group or evidence that recovery would not have occurred without the remedy?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If recovery was compared against a control group, a treatment effect could be assessed.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If recovery commonly occurs without treatment, the causal claim fails.

wise_refusal: We would refuse this causal claim if improvement could plausibly occur without the intervention and no control group is present. That is exactly the situation here, so the claim is invalid.
gold_rationale: Common colds typically resolve on their own within days. The only evidence provided is that the remedy preceded recovery, which is insufficient to establish causation. This is a classic post hoc fallacy.

scenario: In 2008, Oregon expanded Medicaid but had limited enrollment slots. Eligible low-income adults were randomly selected by lottery to receive Medicaid coverage. Individuals who won the lottery obtained insurance, while those who did not remained uninsured. Researchers followed both groups to compare healthcare utilization and health outcomes over time.
claim: Medicaid coverage increases healthcare utilization and improves mental health outcomes.
label: YES

Y.name: Healthcare utilization and mental health outcomes

causal_structure: Lottery -> Medicaid Coverage (X) -> Healthcare Utilization / Mental Health (Y)
key_insight: Random assignment via lottery eliminates selection bias, allowing differences in outcomes to be causally attributed to Medicaid coverage rather than pre-existing differences.
hidden_timestamp: Were health outcomes measured after insurance assignment and sufficient follow-up time to observe effects?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the lottery assignment is respected as random, observed differences in utilization and mental health can be causally attributed to Medicaid coverage.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If selection bias or non-random enrollment were assumed, the causal interpretation would be invalid.

wise_refusal: We would refuse to answer this causal claim if Medicaid enrollment were based on individual choice, health status, or administrative discretion, because self-selection or targeting would introduce confounding that prevents causal inference. However, in this case, coverage was assigned by a random lottery among individuals who all wanted Medicaid, so those refusal conditions do not apply.
gold_rationale: Because Medicaid access was determined by a random lottery among individuals who all desired coverage, the comparison between winners and non-winners approximates a randomized controlled trial. Winners had significantly higher outpatient utilization and lower rates of depression. These differences can be causally attributed to insurance coverage rather than confounding factors.

scenario: Researchers tested whether gene ABC is necessary for tumor growth by creating genetically identical mice, except that one group had gene ABC knocked out. Both groups were exposed to the same carcinogen under identical laboratory conditions. Wild-type mice developed tumors, while ABC-knockout mice did not develop tumors over a 16-week period.
claim: Gene ABC is necessary for tumor growth.
label: YES
causal_structure: Gene ABC (X) -> Tumor Growth (Y)
key_insight: Removing X in a controlled setting and observing disappearance of Y demonstrates necessity and causality.
hidden_timestamp: Were all non-target variables held constant during the ablation experiment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the only difference is removal of gene ABC and tumors disappear, gene ABC is causally necessary.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other experimental conditions differed, the causal claim would be invalid.

wise_refusal: We would refuse this claim if removing gene ABC also altered other pathways or experimental conditions, because the effect could not be attributed solely to ABC. However, the experiment controlled all other factors, so refusal is not warranted.
gold_rationale: The controlled gene knockout removes gene ABC while holding all other variables constant. The disappearance of tumors when ABC is absent demonstrates that ABC is causally necessary for tumor growth.
